definition: A set of rules that allows different software applications to talk to each other. It's like a waiter taking your order to the kitchen and bringing back your food.
A version control system used by developers to track changes in their code. It's like a time machine for your project, so you can go back to a previous version if you make a mistake.
A container for storing data values. In Python, you can create a variable like `name = 'Adrian'` to store the text 'Adrian'.
A block of code which only runs when it is called. It helps organize code and makes it reusable. You can think of it as a recipe that you can use over and over.
A way to execute a block of code repeatedly. For example, a 'for loop' can go through a list of items one by one.
Delivering computing services—including servers, storage, databases, and software—over the Internet ('the cloud').
The standard language used to create and design documents on the World Wide Web. It structures the content of a webpage.
